Award.AwardTitle: Homogeneous Solar Hydrogen Photocatalysis: Sensitizer Design and Mechanistic Insights from Transient Spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Felix Castellano at North Carolina State University is developing new molecular-based hydrogen-generating systems that function with light and in water. While the chemical process of using light to reduce protons to molecular hydrogen is of fundamental technological importance, only a handful of molecular-based systems can accomplish this important transformation in pure water. This research project directly addresses current themes related to the growing demand for renewable energy sources to power the planet in the future and safeguarding global environmental integrity. Students involved in this project are being cross-trained in numerous areas of chemistry. The proposed investigations are not only fostering the scientific and professional education of undergraduate and graduate students engaged in the project, but also are involving these students in regional public scientific education outreach activities.


Professor Castellano is designing new photosensitizers, new classes of electron donors, evaluating the photocatalytic cycle activation pathways (reductive or oxidative electron transfer, triplet energy transfer), and optimizing the compositions of these components to discover the best systems for detailed mechanistic studies using transient spectroscopic methods. The new classes of metal-to-ligand charge transfer sensitizers being synthesizes are based upon water-soluble Ir(III), Ru(II), and Cu(I) complexes. The concept of employing triplet energy transfer shuttles to mediate the initial electron transfer reaction to the requisite cobalt-based water reduction catalyst and/or electron donor species is being studied as well. Performance metrics of these systems are being evaluated in parallel using combinatorial photochemistry, and various analytical approaches are being used to determine the chemical fate of the numerous reaction components and to identify deleterious decomposition pathways. A detailed understanding of the mechanisms of action of the optimized photocatalytic compositions is being gained using a battery of static and dynamic spectroscopic techniques. This interdisciplinary project is contributing to the fundamental knowledge base of converting solar energy into a renewable environmentally friendly, non-carbon-based chemical fuel.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Felix N. Castellano at North Carolina State University focused on developing new molecular-based homogenous hydrogen-generating photocatalytic compositions that function in water. While the chemical process of reducing protons to hydrogen is ubiquitous and of fundamental importance, only a handful of molecular compositions can photocatalytically accomplish this important transformation in pure water. Over the course of this 3-year project, numerous unexpected discoveries were made that required significant experimentation to properly understand. For example, experiments targeting the development of excited state energy transfer processes to absorb sunlight and deliver this energy to catalyst molecules in the form of chemical energy resulted in the observation of photochemical upconversion in water for the first time. Photochemical upconversion is a process where two excited molecules interact in such a manner that their energy combines together on the same molecule, leading to an upper excited state which then emits light characteristic of that upper excited state. This process of upconversion enables the absorption of low energy photons ultimately converting them into higher energy light that is of fundamental importance in solar photochemistry. Similarly, in pursuit of synthesizing new classes of water-soluble visible light absorbing sensitizer molecules, we discovered that these chromophores engaged in completely unexpected aggregation-based self-assembly processes that served to enhance the excited state properties of these molecules. This occurred as a result of the aggregation helping to ?hide? the majority of these molecules from the solvent environment leading to extended excited state lifetimes and light emission quantum efficiencies. Finally, difficulties in detecting metal-hydride intermediates during hydrogen-evolving photocatalysis led to fundamental investigations targeting a comprehensive understanding of the spectroscopic properties of transition metal hydride excited states.

This interdisciplinary research program directly addressed important themes related to the growing demand for renewable energy sources to power the planet in the future, safeguarding global environmental integrity. This experimental work encompassed many aspects of inorganic and organometallic chemistry, multi-electron transfer processes, energy transfer, transient spectroscopy, as well as photochemistry, resulting in students being cross-trained in numerous chemical areas of expertise. These investigations fostered the scientific and professional education of 3 different undergraduate and 3 different graduate students that were engaged in the project, many of which were from underrepresented groups. Two chemistry-based doctoral dissertations were partially supported by this award. Two high school students also participated in this research program. Three different scientific collaborations were also developed as a result of this award and overall generated 6 peer-reviewed research articles published and more than 10 professional scientific presentations had been given before this report submission, including a public presentation on solar energy conversion given by the PI in Raleigh, North Carolina.
